subtopics.title: The Basics
subtopics.description: These tutorials cover basic operations common to many sequence-bases analyses

references.title: QCFAIL
references.summary: Articles about common next-generation sequencing problems

references.title: A quality control system for profiles obtained by ChIP sequencing
references.summary: Presents an approach that associates global and local QC indicators to ChIP-seq data sets as well as to a variety of enrichment-based studies by NGS.

references.title: A survey of best practices for RNA-seq data analysis
references.summary: Highlights the challenges associated with each step of RNA-seq data analysis.

references.title: Summarizing and correcting the GC content bias in high-throughput sequencing
references.summary: Summarizes the many possible sourced of GC bias for deeply sequenced samples.

references.title: Sequencing depth and coverage: key considerations in genomic analyses
references.summary: Discuss the issue of sequencing depth in the design of next-generation sequencing experiments.

references.title: Quality assessment and control of high-throughput sequencing data
references.summary: Collection of papers on quality controls for various NGS applications

references.title: Identification and correction of systematic error in high-throughput sequence data
references.summary: Reviews and proposes correction for systematic base pair errors in deep sequencing

references.title: Heat seq: an interactive web tool for high-throughput sequencing experiment comparison with public data
references.summary: Presents a web-tool that allows genome scale comparison of high throughput experiments

materials.title: Clean and manage Sanger sequences from raw files to aligned consensus
questions: How to clean Sanger sequencing files?
objectives: Learn how to manage sequencing files (AB1, FASTQ, FASTA)
Learn how to clean your Sanger sequences in an automated and reproducible way
key_points: Check your data and results for mistakes afterward !!!! This procedure is useful but not perfect

materials.title: Mapping

objectives: Run a tool to map reads to a reference genome
Explain what is a BAM file and what it contains
Use genome browser to understand your data
key_points: Know your data!
Mapping is not trivial
There are many mapping algorithms, it depends on your data which one to choose

materials.title: Quality Control
questions: How to perform quality control of NGS raw data?
What are the quality parameters to check for a dataset?
How to improve the quality of a dataset?
objectives: Assess short reads FASTQ quality using FASTQE 🧬😎 and FastQC
Assess long reads FASTQ quality using Nanoplot and PycoQC
Perform quality correction with Cutadapt (short reads)
Summarise quality metrics MultiQC
Process single-end and paired-end data
key_points: Perform quality control on every dataset before running any other bioinformatics analysis
Assess the quality metrics and improve quality if necessary
Check the impact of the quality control
Different tools are available to provide additional quality metrics
For paired-end reads analyze the forward and reverse reads together

materials.title: Removal of human reads from SARS-CoV-2 sequencing data
questions: How can you remove traces of human sequence data from a sequenced viral sample?
objectives: Obtain viral (SARS-CoV-2) sequencing data with contaminating human reads from public sources
Organize the data into a collection
Preprocess and map the data against the human reference genome
Eliminate reads/read pairs that map to the human genome from the original data
key_points: Before submitting raw viral sequencing data to public databases you will want to remove human sequence traces
Human reads can be identified by mapping the data to the human reference genome
After mapping, you can extract the read identifiers of the non-human reads and use these to extract just the desired original sequenced reads from the input data

materials.title: Screening assembled genomes for contamination using NCBI FCS
questions: Are the sequences in a genome assembly contaminant-free?
objectives: Learn how to screen a genome assembly for adaptor and vector contamination.
Learn how to screen a genome assembly for non-host organism contamination.
key_points: Contamination can arise from multiple sources and occur at multiple stages of a genome assembly project.
Contamination cleanup is essential for reliable comparative genomics analyses.

workflows.name: NCBI Foreign Contamination Screen
workflows.title: NCBI Foreign Contamination Screen
workflows.description: This workflow performs contamination cleaning steps on assembled genomes. Users specify an input genome (fasta/fasta.gz) and taxonomic information corresponding to the source organism. There are two screening steps for foreign organism sequences (FCS-GX) and adaptors (FCS-adaptor), each followed by a cleaning step to remove identified contaminants. The final output is a cleaned genome.

history.message: Modify NIH funder. Add workflow license URL
Suggested tutorial changes. Add workflow test.
